column4: An influential cultural critic, philosopher, and public intellectual, Said is most famous for his book "Orientalism" in 1978.
A noted historian and indologist, and one of the major influences in the study of South Asia at Oxford University from the 1950s through the 1980s.
Sultan of the Ottoman Empire from 1774 to 1789.
(1905-1974) A Bengali Muslim politician.
The first man created by God in Biblical and Quranic traditions.

(1910-1994)  Ahmed Ali was a famous Pakistani novelist, diplomat, and scholar. He was born in New Dehli, India and educated at the Aligarh and Lucknow universities and taught at many leading Indian universities. He is credited for having written one of the greatest novels about New Dehli.
(1769-1859) Alexander von Humboldt was a Prussian geographer, naturalist and explorer. Humboldt's quantitative work on botanical geography laid the foundation for the field of biogeography.

(1922-2009) Ali Akbar Khan was a Hindutani Classical musician who was born in Comilla, East Bengal. He was especially famous for his skill in playing the sarod.  He established music schools in Calcutta, Switzerland, and California, helping to popularize Indian Classical music in the West.
Nephew and son-in-law of the prophet Muhammad, he was the fourth caliph of Islam.
Nawab of Bengal between 1740 and 1756.
19th century Austrian orientalist.
Renowned economist and Nobel Laureate.  Sen is famous for his development of rational choice theory, and his contributions to Development Economics and Philosophy.  He teaches at Harvard University.
Leading economist and political philosopher from Kolkata.  Datta served as Vice Chancellor of Viswa Bharati University.
(1741-1795) French adventurer and soldier who made his career in 18th century India.
(1889-1970) Iconic British historian celebrated for his twelve volume work on the rise and fall of civilizations.

A world renowned 19th century French philosopher.  His philosophy of Positivism, with its emphasis on science and progress towards greater social rationality, had a strong reception in Calcutta in the late 19th century.
A wife of the prophet Muhammad and also daughter of the first caliph Abu Bakr.
Professor of History at Tufts University
Chief Minister of West Bengal from 1948 to 1962
(1891-1956) Charismatic leader of the Dalits and an Indian politician who helped frame the constitution.
Founder of the Mughal empire in India, which he ruled from 1526 to 1530.

(1872-1970) British mathemtician, philosopher, and public intellectual.  Bertrand Russell was one of the most influential commentators on the challenges to democratic society from the 1920s through the 1950s.
Sociologist whose research focuses on religiously-based discord in South Asia
The younger brother of Vivekananda,  he was a Marxist intellectual, as well as a global traveler in the period of Indian anti-colonial struggle.
Packard Chair of Theology at Tufts University
(1926-1996) A historian of India
A 20th century German philosopher and political theorist
An influential British Marxist historian who focused on early modern English history.  He was a major contributor to the History Workshop group.
An American-born economist who made contributions to the study of the agricultural economy.  He is significant for bringing peasants into the study of South Asian history.
(1711-1776) Scottish philosopher and economist associated with empiricism
An American scholar of South Asian history, Kopf made important contributions to the study of the intellectual history of Bengal in the 19th century.

Bengali historian who specializes in postcolonial theory and subaltern studies. He was educated at Presidency College and the Indian Institute for Management in Kolkata, before finishing his PhD at the Australian National University. He is currently a professor at the University of Chicago.
An 18th century English historian most famous for writing "The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire."
Professor of Cultural Anthropology and History at Duke University
A British Marxist historian who was born in Egypt and grew up in Vienna.  He has provided foundational perspectives on British history, European history, and nationalist movements.
(1902-1994) A developmental psychologist known for his theories of the life cycles and identity crisis.
The first woman created by God in Biblical and Quranic traditions
A 20th century Urdu poet
Mughal emperor from 1713 to 1719
Daughter of the prophet Muhammad.
A scholar, literary critic, and translator important in the establishment of postcolonial studies in Western academia.
An 18th century Indian historian.
A philologist who later specialized in archaeology. He was famous for his Marxist study of archaeology. Childe was a major figure among academics of the British Left.
Professor of History at Emory University
Associate professor of History at National University of Singapore
A Bengali-Pakistani politician
Grandson of the prophet Muhammad and son of Ali, the fourth Islamic caliph
Indian historian of the acient period.  He taught at Presidency College, the University of Calcutta, and the University of Dacca.
Homi Bhaba is a professor of the humanities at Harvard University.  He specializes in postcolonial studies.
Grandson of the prophet Muhammad and son of Ali, he was killed by the Umayyads in Battle of Karbala.
Ruler of Mysore from 1761 to 1782

Moroccan explorer known for his extensive travels, accounts of which were published in the Rihla over a period of thirty years. Visited most of the known Islamic world as well as many non-Muslim lands. His journeys included trips to North Africa, the Horn of Africa, West Africa and Eastern Europe in the West, and to the Middle East, South Asia, Central Asia, Southeast Asia and China in the East.
(1724-1804) Philosopher of the German Englightenment.
Prime Minister of the Republic of India for three consecutive terms from 1966 to 1977, and again from 1980 to 1984.  She was the daughter of Jawaharlal Nehru.
(1953-2003) Reader in History at the Aligarh Muslim University
(1897-1956)  A French Noble Prize winning chemist
Eminent Indian Marxist historian, who has published on medieval and early modern India as well as Indo-Islamic society and civilization.
Professor Emeritus of History at Stockholm University

Foundational figure in South Asian history writing, Sarkar pioneered the study of Mughal History.  He taught at the University of Calcutta, Dhaka University and Madras University.  He is considered one of the most influential early twentieth century Indian scholars.
A renowned economist and currently a professor as the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia university.
Mughal emperor who ruled from 1712 to 1713.
(1773-1836)  Scottish historian and Utilitarian philosopher
A historian of the Mughal Empire
Professor of History at Cambridge University
(1934-2006) Founder of the Bahujan Samajwadi Party
A political scientist, born in Czechoslovakia and of German descent.  Deutsch made important contributions to communication theory, system theory and cybernetics.  He taught at Harvard University.

Eminent Bengali writer, educationist and intellectual.  Wadud taught at Presidency College as well as Dhaka Intermediate College.  He completed a dictionary of Bangla words derived from Arabic, Persian, and Turkish in 1953.
A scholar of cultural history in the 1970s and 1980s, hecombined interests in anthropology and literature, with his study of history.
Professor of History at the University of Chicago
The first wife of Muhammad, the prophet of Islam
Assistant Professor of History at Tufts University

Krishna Bose is an eminent writer, educationist and parliamentarian.  She has been a Member of Parliament in India in the 11th, 12th and 13th (1996-2004) Lok Sabhas. During the term of the 13th Lok Sabha, she served as Chairperson of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on External Affairs in India.
Professor of History at Penn State
L.K. Advani is an Indian politician.  Born in 1927, he joined the RSS in 1942.  He was deputy prime minister from 2002 to 2004. Advani is a leader of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party.
The first Prime Minister of Pakistan and an important Muslim League and Pakistani politician.
Roman historian who lived in the early Roman Empire.
Governor General of the British East India Company from 1786 to 1793.
King of France from 1774 to 1791.
Leading Indian Marxist philosopher active from the 1920s until the decade after Indian independence.
Considered the founder of Indian sociology, his work focused on village communities, the caste system, social status and patterns of stratification.
A Maratha general and ruler of the state of Gwalior in the 18th century
The fourteenth prime minister of India.  Singh is an economist, who, in his position as Finance Minister in 1991, began a process of major economic reforms.
A scholar of Chinese History at Australian National University
(1893-1956) Indian astrophysicist
(1926-1984) French philosopher, sociologist and historian who laid the foundation for new approaches to social thought.
Nawab of Bengl from 1760 to 1763.
18th century Urdu poet.
19th century Urdu and Persian poet.
Persian adventurer in the Mughal court during the 18th century.
An 18th century Urdu poet.
A leader of the All-India Muslim League, the founder of Pakistan and its first Governor General
Nawab of Arcot in India from 1752 to 1795
(570-632) The Prophet of Islam.
20th century Urdu poet and intellectual.
Mughal emperor from 1719 to 1748.
(1905-2004) Indian writer whose work focused on the socio-economically poor class of Indian society.
A scholar of Indo-Islamic studies, and past vice-chancellor of Jamia Milia Islamia University in Delhi.
The Shah of Iran from 1736 to 1747 and the founder of the Afsharid dynasty.
French military and political leader during the later stages of the French Revolution. He was the Emperor of France from 1804 to 1814.
Chief Minister of Gujarat and a Bharatiya Janata Party representative.
Italian historian and philosopher who lived during the Renaissance

One of the most influential Bengali authors writing in English in the twentieth century.  He is celelbrated for his "Autobiography of an Unknown Indian."  Chaudhuri served as the secretary to Sarat Chandra Bose.
The second Mughal emperor who reigned from 1530-1540.
A Sufi saint from the Chishti order who died in Delhi in 1325
20th century German sociologist.
Persian physician of the 17th century who was patronized by the Mughal court.
Professor of economic history at the Delhi School of Economics.  Prakash's work has dealt with the East India Company trade and finance as well as Indian merchants in the early modern period.

Political scientist and historian who specializes in the study of Bengal and South Asia.  Chatterjee was a leading member of the Subaltern Studies Collective and has made significant contributions to postcolonial theory. He received his degrees from the Presidency College and the University of Rochester.
Former reader in Art History at Sussex University
Title for the rulers of the Maratha Empire
Greek historian from the Hellenistic Period
A political scientist and philosopher, celebrated for his application of the "linguistic turn" to the study of political discourse.  Skinner teaches at the University of London.

(1772-1883) One of the first modernizers in Bengal, credited with the establishment of a new religious order, the Brahmo Samaj, and the creation of a new modern sensibility in literature, philosophy and social thought among the Bengali bhadralok.

Noted historian of South Asian history in the 19th and 20th centuries, Ray has contributed to the study of the "bazaar" economic relations across the Indian Ocean, as well as the nationalist struggle in Bengal.  He is Vice Chancellor of Viswa Bharati University, Shantiniketan.
Professor of History at the University of Delaware
A South Asian historian influential in the Subaltern Studies group.
The first Maharaja of the Sikh Empire ruling from 1801 to 1839
(1920-2012) World famous sitar player, originally from Kolkata.
Professor of Sociology at the India Institute of Technology in Delhi.
Governor General of the British East India Company from 1793 to 1805
Governor General of the British East India Company from 1757 to 1760
Saartjie Baartman was born in 1789 in Easter Cape in the Dutch Empire. She was a famous KhoiKhoi woman who was exhibited at freak show attractions in 19th century Europe.
A Muslim ruler in the Middle Ages famous for recapturing Jerusalem from Christian crusaders in 1187.  He ruled over Syria and Egypt from 1174 to 1193.
Professor of History at University of California, Los Angeles
Associate Professor of Anthropology at Tufts University
(1889-1950) An Indian politician who played an important role in India's struggle for independence
Nawab of Bengal from 1739 to 1740

An Indian historian who graduated from Presidency College, Madras and finished his PhD at Oxford University.  He was Reader in Indian History at St. Athonys College, Oxford before joining the newly established Jawaharlal Nehru University in 1969.
Professor of History at Jamia Millia Islamia, Delhi
Sultan of the Ottoman Empire from 1789 to 1807
Mughal emperor from 1759 to 1806
Mughal emperor from 1627 to 1658
Professor of History at the University of Dehli.
Indian Islamic scholar and Naqshbandi Sufi who lived in the late sixteenth/early seventeenth century
Professor of Sanskrit and Indian Studies at Columbia University
Nawab of Oudh from 1753 to 1775
An Indian minister and politician.

(1746-1794) One of the founders of Brisith colonial Oriental scholarship.  As a philologist, Jones studied ancient Sanskrit texts both in pursuit of the archaic glory of the Orient, but also in order to derive codes of law to adapt British institutions for the colonial project.
The last independent Nawab of Bengal ruling from 1756 to 1757
Sudhindranath Dutta was a Bengali post-modern poet, essayist, journalist and critic. Sudhindranath is one of the most notable poets after the Tagore-era in Bengali literature.

Subhas Chandra Bose, also known as Netaji (Hindi/Bengali: “Respected Leader”), was an Indian nationalist who attempted unsuccessfully to liberate India from British rule with a small military force during the waning years of World War II.
Professor of History at Harvard University
The Indonesian president from 1968 to 1998
A Bengali linguist and educationist.
Indonesian politician who was elected president in 2004.
An intellectual of the Calcutta Left in the 1930s and 1940s.  Sarkar was also a professor of History at Presidency College and the teacher of a loose "school" of young Bengali historians.
A powerful Mughal general of the early 18th century
Professor of History at National University of Singapore
Retired reader of South Asian History at St. Anthony's College, Oxford
English philosopher, historian, and sociologist.
(1588-1679)  17th century English political philosopher
14th century conqueror
Ruler of Mysore from 1782 to 1799
Indian feminist and historian. She is also the founder of India's first feminist publishing house, Kali for Women
The philosophical doctrine that actions are right if they are useful or beneficial for the majority
Dean of the John Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies and former Professor of International Politics at The Fletcher School, Tufts University
Portuguese explorer and the commander of the first ships to sail from Europe to India.
Prominent Indian economist, responsible for founding the Delhi School of Economics.
Governor General of the British East India Company from 1774 to 1785
(1910–2003) British explorer and travel writer.
Professor of History at the University of Amsterdam
Led the British East India Company in the Battle of Pollilur against Mysore in 1780

Reader in Modern Asian History at Birkbeck College, University of London. Amrith’s research is on the history of the Bay of Bengal region since the late 18th century with a focus on the history of migration and cultural circulation between south India and Southeast Asia.
Traveller who voyaged from Penang to Kolkata through the Bay of Bengal in 1810.

Professor of Southeast Asian History at University of Hawaii at Manoa. His concentration is in the modern history of Southeast Asia, particularly that of Malaysia, Indonesia, the southern Philippines, and southern Thailand.
(1796–1854) A Malayan writer of Indian origin.
Islamic preacher in Tamil Nadu and a 13th generation descendant of the renowned Sufi saint, Hajrath Muhiyudin Abd al-Qadir al-Jalani.
Chinese printer
Publisher of the Tamil magazine, Tangai Nesan
The 99th caliph of Islam and the 34th sultan of the Ottoman Empire. He was the last Sultan to exert effective control over the Ottoman Empire.
(1819–1901) Monarch of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland from1837 until her death in 1876.  She used the additional title "Empress of India."

Lecturer for Tamil language and culture at the University of Goettingen.  His main interests are the history of religion in South India and Tamil literature with a focus on Islam and Muslim communities, as well as historical and contemporary links between South India and Southeast Asia.
Muslim Indonesian Intellectual
(1901-1970) The first President of Indonesia.
Professor of History at University of Witwatersrand, Johannesburg
Professor at Centre for Social Studies, Jawaharlal Nehru University
(1958-2012) Taught history at Penn State, specializing in the Early Modern period
(1769-1849) Ottoman general who became ruler of Egypt, and founder of modern-day Egypt
(1722-1772) Founder of the Durrani Empire in Afghanistan, won the Third Battle of Panipat
Roman historian who wrote a history of Rome
(1864-1920) German sociologist, one of the founders of social theory
Famous Sufi based in Baghdad
Political activist and Islamic ideologist in the Muslim world during the late 19th century, he advocated Islamic modernity and Pan-Islamism
(1916-2000) Professor of Comparitive Religion at Harvard University
Professor of History at University of California, Berkeley
(1924-1993) British historical socialist and campaigner.
(1818-1883) German philosopher, historian, sociologist
Professor of sociology and comparative religion at the University of Washington
Raja who played active role in Bihar during the Battle of Buxar
Historian of early modern India who has worked on Tipu Sultan
Sixth Mughal Emperor (1618-1707)
Wadiyar Prime Minister of Mysore deposed by Hyder Ali
(1926-1996) Scholar of India
Armenian general who led Mir Qasim's army in the Battle of Buxar
French Governor General of Pondicherry in the 18th century.
Associate Professor of History at Cornell University
(1746-1794) British philologist and orientalist
Professor of History at Swansea University
Professor of Geography at Queen Mary University of London
(1729-1797) Irish enlightenment thinker
(1905-1975) American literary critic
(1812-1857) British journalist and satirist
A maharaja who in 1781 led a rebellion against the British temporarily taking control of a British fort in Northern India
Professor of South Asian Languages and Civilizations at the University of Chicago
A munshi in the court at Murshidabad
A munshi in the court at Murshidabad
(1731-1805) French scholar of Indian culture
(1712-1786) King of Prussia from 1740 to 1786
Scholar and cultural historian of 18th century France
American journalist who writes about foreign policy and international affairs
Professor of Oceanic History and Affairs at Harvard University
Historian and past Fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge
President of the United States of America from 2001 to 2009.
Leader of the Soviet Union from 1922 to 1952.
Chancellor of Germany from 1933 to 1945.
(1893-1976) First chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China.
President of Iraq from 1979 to 2003, he was deposed by the UK and the USA when they invaded Iraq in 2003.
Prime Minister of Pakistan from 1988 to 1990 and from 1993 to 1995.  She was assassinated in 2007 while campaigning for reelection.
Burmese opposition politician who placed under house arrest by the government from 1989 until her release in 2010.  In 2012 she was elected to the lower house of the Burmese parliament.

Deputy Chairman of the Executive Council of Burma from 1946 to 1947.  He played a leading role in Burmese independence from Great Britain.  He is the father of Burmese opposition politician Aung San Suu Kyi.
United States Senator representing Virginia from 2007 to 2013.  Webb was on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and worked and travelled extensively in Southeast Asia.
Prime Minister of India.  He was elected to office in 2004.
(635-713 CE) Chinese Buddhist monk who translated Buddhist texts from Sanskrit to Chinese.  He was a scholar at Nalanda.
Seventh century Chinese Buddhist scholar who visited Nalanda.
A Bengali Indian fiction writer
General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China from 2002 to 2012.
16th century Spanish explorer of the Americas.
Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs from 2009 to 2013
Indian academic and foreign policy analyst.
American diplomat.  He was the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs from 1977 to 1981.
(1957-2011) Founder of al-Qaeda, a Sunni militant Islamist organization that is classified as a terrorist organization by the United States.
(1861-1941) Bengali intellectual who advocated independence from Britain and played a major role in the Bengal Renaissance.
British writer and historian specializing in Asian history.

(1811-1873) An assistant surgeon in the First Anglo-Afghan War who was rumored to be the sole survivor of the 4,500 British soldiers deployed to Afghanistan.  Historical research has since revealed that there were, in fact, multiple survivors of the war.
(1785-1842)  Rule of the Durrani Empire from 1803 to 1809 and again from 1839 to 1842.
(1805-1841) Scottish traveller and explorer who played a major role in the First Anglo-Afghan War.
(1784-1849)  British Whig politician and the Governor-General of India from 1836 to 1842.  He initiated the First Anglo-Afghan War in 1838 by dethroning Dost Mahommed Khan.
(1793-1863) Founder of the Barakzai dynasty and Emir of Afghanistan from 1826 to 1839 and from 1845 to 1863.
(1790-1853)  Wife of Sir Robert Henry Sale, a British army officer.  She was kidnapped in the First Anglo-Afghan War and held hostage for nine months.
(1789-1856) Anglo-Irish soldier and first Governor of Hong Kong.
(1796-1855) Emperor of Russia from 1825 to 1855.
(1794-1861) Agent to the Governor-General for the Affairs of the Punjab and North-West Frontier.

column2: Mohan Lal Kashmiri; Mohan Lal Zutshi
column4: (1812-1877) Traveller, diplomat, and spy who played a major role in the First Anglo-Afghan War.  He wrote an authoritative biography of Dost Mohammad Khan.
(1810-1895)  British East India Company army officer who advocated for more British activity in Afghanistan to prevent possible Russian control of the region.
(1782-1842) British general who commanded the British garrison in Kabul during the First Anglo-Afghan War.
President of Afghanistan elected to office in 2004.
(1780-1839) Founder of the Sikh Empire and its ruler from 1801-1839.
(971-1030 CE) Ruler of the Ghaznavid Empire from 998 to 1002.
(1790-1871)  British Tory politician who served as Governor-General of India from 1842 to 1844.
Afghan Kohistani resistance leader during the First Anglo-Afghan War.
(1816-1845) Afghan emir from 1842 to 1845, he was a prominent leader in the First Anglo-Afghan War in which he successfully defeated the British garrison of 4,500 soldiers in Kabul.

(1793-1841) British civil servant in India.  He was an adviser of Lord Auckland and supported the policy of dethroning Dost Mahommed Khan in favor of Shah Shuja.  Macnaghten was assassinated by Dost Mahommed's son in 1841.
Former Assistant Professor of History at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.  In 2013 she was appointed an Assistant Professor of History at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
(1832-1922)  British administrator in Zanzibar.
(1858-1945) British colonial administrator in Africa.
(1874-1965) British politician, he was prime minister from 1940 to 1945.
(1862-1931) British diplomat who served as Commissioner of British East Africa from 1900 to 1904.
(1868-1933) British diplomat who served as the Viceroy of India from 1916 to 1921.
(1868-1938) Served as Secretary of State for the Colonies from 1922 to 1924.
(1913-1973) A union leader in Kenya who established trade unionism in Kenya.
(1879-1924) British politician who served as Secretary of State for India from 1917 to 1922.
(1854-1925) British statesman who served as Secretary of State for the Colonies from 1919 to 1921.
Chair of Modern Asian History at the University of Amsterdam.
A Bangladeshi business family that dates from the late 18th century.  The family owns M.M. Ispahani Limited.
(1524-1580) Famous Portuguese poet.
14th century Chinese military officer who was instrumental in the formation of the Ming Dynasty.
Professor of Colonial and Global History at the University of Leiden.
Professor of History at the University of Hyderabad.
15th century Islamic preacher who became a very preacher in Chittagong.
Professor in the Department of History at UCLA.
Honorary reader in history at the University of Sydney.
British historian specializing in global history.
Professor at the European University Institute in Florence, Italy.
Professor of History and Religious Studies at Yale University.
Professor in the Department of History at the University of Florida.
Professor of Asian Studies at William Paterson University.
(1915-1993) Middle East historian who wrote the famous "A History of the Arab Peoples."
Professor of History at the University of California, Davis.
British historian specializing in the history of Islam.
Professor of History at the University of Bremen.
Lecturer of Tamil language and culture at the University of Göttingen.
Professor of Comparative Studies at The Ohio State University.
Professor of History at the University of Bergen.
Professor of History at the University of California, Los Angeles.
(1844-1906) Indian lawyer and third president of the Indian National Congress.
Reader in South Asian Studies at the University of Oxford.
Professor of Divinity at Harvard Divinity School.
Senior Researcher at the Chr. Michelsen Institute, Norway.
Associate Professor of History at Northern Arizona University.
Reader in Southeast Asian and Imperial History, Magdalene College, Cambridge.
Pakistani political author and the former Pakistani Ambassador to the United States.
Assistant Professor of Government and Politics in the Department of Public and International Affairs at George Mason University.
(1788–1824) English poet and a leading figure in the Romantic movement.
(1869–1957) Chinese physician who promoted social and educational reforms in Singapore in the early 20th century.
(1870-1924) Russian communist revolutionary, politician and political theorist. He served as the leader of the Russian SFSR and as Premier of the Soviet Union.
(1885–1972) Professor at Harvard Law School, High Commissioner of the Philippines
(1867–1940) Pioneer of Vietnamese 20th century nationalism.
(1866–1925) Chinese revolutionary, first president and founding father of the Republic of China.
(1891-1937) Indian revolutionary and co-founder of the Communist Party of India.
(1886–1945) Revolutionary leader against the British Raj in India and was one of the key organisers of the Ghadar Revolution and later, the Indian National Army.
(1879–1950) Indonesian freedom fighter and politician of Indo descent.
(1884- 1939) Indian nationalist revolutionary who founded the Ghadar Party in America.
Jatindranath Mukherjee (1879 –1915) was a Bengali revolutionary philosopher against British rule.
(1897-1949) Indonesian philosopher and teacher.
(1908–1961) French phenomenological philosopher, strongly influenced by Edmund Husserl and Martin Heidegger.
(1921–1988) Welsh academic, novelist and critic.
(1890-1969) Vietnamese communist revolutionary leader who was prime minister (1945–1955) and president (1945–1969) of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam (North Vietnam).
(1954-) Taiwanese-born American film director, screenwriter and producer.
(1958-) A Hong Kong "Second Wave" filmmaker
(1872–1926) Famous early 20th century Vietnamese nationalist.
(1897–1990) German sociologist of Jewish descent, who later became a British citizen. He is especially famous for his theory of civilizing (and decivilizing) processes.
Author of the Tibe Dara Shikohi, a Mughal Unani medical text.
(1592-1666) Fifth Mughal Emperor who reigned from 1628 until 1658
(1703–1762) Islamic scholar, reformer and founder of modern Islamic thought who attempted to reassess Islamic theology in the light of modern changes
(1564–1624) Indian Islamic scholar from Punjab, a Hanafi jurist, and a prominent member of the Naqshband_ Sufi order.
(1713–1781) Urdu language poet.
(1911-1984)  Famous revolutionary poet of the Urdu and Punjabi languages from Pakistan.
Assistant Professor at Department of Anthropology, Tufts University
Reader in South Asian and Indian Ocean Studies, De Montfort University, Leicester, UK
(1911–1980) Canadian philosopher of communication theory and a public intellectual who coined the term "the global village."
(1894–1952)  Canadian professor of political economy at the University of Toronto and the author of seminal works on media, communication theory and Canadian economic history.
